3.72.text:
>>The Prime Minister (Mr David Cameron): This
morning I had meetings with ministerial colleagues

17.14.text:
and others, and in addition to my duties in
this House, I will have further such meetings

22.63.text:
>>Mims Davies: Emily Davison died on 8 June
1913. Yesterday, we commemorated women’s

31.46.text:
suffrage and the importance of votes for women—and
women voting for women, of course. Thousands

38.09.text:
wanted to register to vote yesterday but were
unable to due to massive demand. Will the

42.89.text:
PM update the House on what he is doing to
ensure that everyone has the chance to register

48.74.text:
to vote and can do so in this vital vote for
a generation?

53.71.text:
>>The Prime Minister: First of all, let me
join my hon. Friend in remembering what the

58.80.text:
suffragettes stood for, what they achieved
and the fact that we achieved universal suffrage

64.49.text:
in this country. She raises voter registration
and I am sure that the whole House will want

68.50.text:
to know what the situation is. Look, it is
extremely welcome that so many people want

73.40.text:
to take part in this massive democratic exercise
and in this vital decision for our country.

78.83.text:
Last night, there was record demand on the
gov.uk website from people concerned that

83.13.text:
they might not be registered to vote in the
referendum, which overloaded the system. I

88.28.text:
am clear that people should continue to register
today. The Electoral Commission made a statement

93.54.text:
this morning, urging the Government to consider
options that would effectively extend the

98.09.text:
deadline, which should include legislative
options, and we are doing that and discussing

102.40.text:
it with the commission today. We are working
urgently with it to do just that and to ensure

107.76.text:
that those who register today and those who
registered last night will be able to vote

114.21.text:
>>Jeremy Corbyn (Islington North) (Lab): I
think it would be appropriate if the House

120.65.text:
recognised and remembered the life of Muhammad
Ali. He was not only the greatest in his chosen

126.56.text:
field, but someone whose courage and wit inspired
so many. Indeed, I had the honour of meeting

131.20.text:
him in London in the 1980s and met his wife
Lonnie with Doreen Lawrence only a couple

135.93.text:
of weeks ago. I think we should commend his
bravery in facing Parkinson’s disease and

141.14.text:
his courageous campaigning on civil rights,
anti-racism and peace. Truly, all of us have

148.89.text:
Yesterday, I met some workers from Sports
Direct who were coming to Parliament to give

155.39.text:
evidence to the Select Committee on Business,
Innovation and Skills about the company’s

157.92.text:
shocking behaviour, including non-payment
of the minimum wage and a culture of intimidation

163.75.text:
and fear on top of the insecurity and exploitation
of zero-hours contracts. Philip wrote to me

170.79.text:
this week with his concerns and said that
the scandalous scourge of zero-hours contracts

177.55.text:
is blighting the lives of many already low-paid
people. Will the Prime Minister do what some

183.43.text:
other European countries have done and ban
exploitative zero-hours contracts here?

188.79.text:
>>The Prime Minister: Let me join the Leader
of the Opposition in paying tribute to the

193.77.text:
life of Muhammad Ali. He was a hero in the
ring and an enormous role model outside the

199.06.text:
ring. What he did in terms of breaking down
barriers and encouraging integration is something

205.16.text:
we should all celebrate. When standing at
this Dispatch Box, I am sure that we all try

208.75.text:
to float like a butterfly and sting like a
bee, although that is not always possible

212.91.text: in the circumstances that we face.

215.59.text:
On Sports Direct, I absolutely abhor the appalling
practice of not paying the minimum wage, and

223.70.text:
this Government have done more than any previous
Government to crack down on non-payment. We

229.23.text:
have levied almost 5,000 penalties since 2010.
We continue to name and shame eligible employers

236.28.text:
when the investigation has been closed, something
which did not happen before. Penalties for

242.12.text:
not paying the minimum wage are at a record
high, and the total value of penalties last

247.26.text:
year was over 15 times bigger than in 2010.
On top of our national living wage, we are

253.96.text:
going after unscrupulous employers and making
sure that people get the deal that they deserve.

259.52.text:
On the issue of zero-hours contracts, we legislated
in the last Parliament to stop exclusive zero-hours

269.10.text:
contracts, but we followed the conclusions
of our consultation, which said that we should

275.46.text:
not go further than that and that some people
want to have the choice of those contracts.

281.89.text:
>>Jeremy Corbyn: The case of Sports Direct
shows that Mike Ashley certainly is not Father

288.80.text:
Christmas. Indeed, he makes Scrooge look like
a good employer. I think we should commend

294.19.text:
Unite the union and its members for exposing
what went on. It shows that we must strengthen,

300.29.text:
not weaken, workers’ rights, particularly
when criminal activity is involved.

305.15.text:
However, the Government’s Employment Minister,
the right hon. Member for Witham (Priti Patel),

309.59.text: said that if we leave Europe,

311.48.text:
“we could just halve the burdens of the
EU social and employment legislation”.

318.28.text:
Perhaps the Prime Minister can help us. Does
she speak on behalf of the Government when

324.32.text:
she promises to reduce the “burdens”,
as she describes them, of employment legislation,

329.68.text: or on behalf of whom does she speak?

331.52.text:
>>The Prime Minister: The Government are in
favour of staying in a reformed European Union

337.33.text:
because we are stronger, safer and better
off. One reason that many people will want

343.66.text:
to stay in the European Union is that they
believe it provides an underpinning of rights

349.63.text:
for workers and employment rights. I would
make the point, in addition, that we in this

354.41.text:
House have repeatedly chosen to go over and
above those rights: we have had the right

360.46.text:
to request flexible working for all workers
since 2014; we went well beyond the EU directive

368.12.text:
on maternity leave by giving 52 weeks’ maternity
leave; we have provided shared parental leave;

373.11.text:
and we give eight days more annual leave to
full-time workers than the EU working time

378.30.text:
directive. I believe that this modern, compassionate
Conservative Government have an excellent

382.96.text:
record on these things, underpinned by our
membership of the European Union.

389.03.text:
>>Jeremy Corbyn: If this is a modern, compassionate
Conservative Government, as the Prime Minister

394.76.text:
describes them, why do they have an Employment
Minister who wants to reduce the “burdens”,

400.58.text:
as she describes them, of employment legislation
and make work less secure? I will quote one

409.13.text:
other person who has given some opinions on
these matters:

412.71.text:
“I can’t guarantee every person currently
in work in their current job will keep their

420.59.text:
That was the right hon. Member for Surrey
Heath (Michael Gove), who is the Justice Secretary.

424.86.text:
He seems equally relaxed about employment
rights. The Prime Minister has an Employment

430.78.text:
Minister and a Justice Secretary who want
to reduce workers’ protections, which they

433.23.text:
describe as a “burden”. Can’t he do
something about that?

436.70.text:
>>The Prime Minister: As the right hon. Gentleman
knows, we are holding a referendum. That is

444.92.text:
what is happening. The Government have a very
clear position, which is that we are stronger,

449.05.text:
safer and better off inside the European Union.
That is the advice that we are giving to voters

453.97.text:
in our country, but of course there are Ministers
in the Government who, in a personal capacity,

459.44.text:
are campaigning on another side of the argument.
I do not agree with them—I do not agree

465.29.text:
with what my right hon. Friend the Member
for Surrey Heath (Michael Gove) said and I

468.22.text:
do not agree with what my right hon. Friend
the Member for Witham (Priti Patel) said.

471.79.text:
I could not be clearer about that. The Government
have a clear position.

476.91.text:
On this issue, not only do the right hon.
Gentleman and I agree—not only do the Conservative

481.10.text:
Government and the Labour party agree—but
we have the support of the Liberal Democrats,

485.67.text:
the support of the Ulster Unionist party and
the support of the Green party. This is one

492.02.text:
occasion when business, large and small, and
the trade unions are on the same side. I think

498.30.text:
that we should celebrate that, and get out
and campaign as hard as we can.

502.30.text:
>>Jeremy Corbyn: What I do celebrate is the
work done by trade unions all across Europe

508.48.text:
that persuaded the European Union to bring
in four weeks’ paid holiday, laws against

514.30.text:
sex discrimination, rights for part-time workers
and rights for agency workers.

521.65.text:
Two weeks ago, I raised with the Prime Minister
the proposed amendment to the posting of workers

527.49.text:
directive, which would close a loophole that
allows unscrupulous employers to exploit migrant

534.16.text:
workers and undercut wages here. Will he now
reply to my question and confirm that he will

540.86.text:
argue in Europe for that amendment to close
the loophole that allows this exploitation

547.53.text:
>>The Prime Minister: As I have said, we support
the current draft. We want to see this sorted

552.23.text:
out. We have been working with the Dutch Prime
Minister who is leading this work, and we

555.75.text:
think that an amendment would be worth while.
The current draft is good and we back it.

560.65.text:
>>Jeremy Corbyn: I am very pleased that the
Prime Minister backs the amendment, but I

564.17.text:
hope that he backs it to ensure that it goes
through. Another issue that I raised with

568.98.text:
him a couple of weeks ago is the anger over
tax avoidance that exists all over this country

576.25.text:
and indeed all over the western world. I agree
that we are more likely to make progress on

582.54.text:
tax avoidance inside the European Union than
outside it, but his Members of the European

588.59.text:
Parliament have not been supporting country-by-country
tax transparency, which would force companies

595.43.text:
to publish their tax payments in each country
in which they operate. Will he now tell us

601.79.text:
when that will be supported by his MEPs and
when it will go through so that we can close

606.78.text:
down just one of the many tax loopholes that
currently exist?

611.62.text:
>>The Prime Minister: I would argue that no
Government have done more nationally to crack

616.99.text:
down on tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance.
I would also argue that no Government have

622.52.text:
done more internationally to bring this up
the international agenda: I made it the centrepiece

627.73.text:
at the G8; we have driven change in the OECD;
and we are now driving change in the European

632.96.text:
Union. Let me confirm that my MEPs do support
country-by-country reporting, and they have

639.22.text:
said that over and again, and I am happy to
repeat it again today.

643.11.text:
>>Jeremy Corbyn: I am really pleased that
the Prime Minister’s MEPs support this transparency;

646.74.text:
we are all delighted about that. I just hope
that they get round to voting for it when

651.69.text:
the opportunity comes up, because that would
certainly help. He will be aware that Labour’s

656.72.text:
position is that we want to stay in the European
Union to improve workers’ rights, tackle

662.77.text:
exploitation, and drive down tax evasion and
tax avoidance, but we are concerned that those

670.64.text:
issues are not the priorities of members of
his Government and his party, such as the

676.81.text:
hon. Member for Uxbridge and South Ruislip
(Boris Johnson), and the right hon. Members

678.56.text:
for Surrey Heath and for Witham. They are
talking about trying to destroy any of the

686.71.text:
social advances made within the European Union.
Does he talk to them about that at any time?

691.82.text:
Do they speak for themselves or for him and
his Government? If they speak for themselves,

696.48.text: how are they Ministers at the same time?

699.48.text:
>>The Prime Minister: Here I am trying to
be so consensual. I am doing my best. I could

705.00.text:
mention that the right hon. Member for Birmingham,
Edgbaston (Ms Stuart) was out yesterday spinning

708.11.text:
for Nigel Farage, but I do not want to play
that game. I want to stress the unity of purpose

715.43.text:
that exists, particularly over the issue of
tax evasion, because there is a serious point

719.43.text:
here. What we have in prospect in the European
Union, in part because of British action,

725.52.text:
is the idea of saying that if large foreign
multinationals want to invest in the European

731.47.text:
Union, they will have to report their country-by-country
tax arrangements not just in Europe, but all

737.54.text:
over the world. That could drive a huge change
in some of these very large companies in which

743.93.text:
there are great concerns. I hope that the
right hon. Gentleman and I can unite and say

748.43.text:
that this would be a good thing, as it shows
that when Britain pushes an agenda in Europe

752.22.text: it wins, and it wins for our citizens.

754.94.text:
>>Richard Drax (South Dorset) (Con): The Prime
Minister has repeatedly stated that he secured

761.08.text:
changes to reform the EU. Will he now confirm
that, on 23 June, the voters are not guaranteed

769.20.text:
any treaty change in EU law as no treaty change
was achieved despite a promise to deliver

776.13.text:
one, and that an international agreement cannot
change EU law? Finally, will he stop denigrating

784.24.text:
our great country, because it is a sign, if
any were needed, that he is losing the argument?

789.85.text:
>>The Prime Minister: I know that my hon.
Friend has very strong views on this issue,

795.83.text:
and I have very strong views on it, too. On
the specific point that he raises, I am afraid

800.56.text:
that he is not correct. In the renegotiation,
we secured two vital treaty changes: one on

806.76.text:
getting Britain out of ever-closer union;
and the other on the protection for our currency.

813.08.text:
I do not accept for one minute that supporting
Britain being a member of a reformed European

820.16.text:
Union is in any way doing our country down.
If you love your country, you want it to be

824.65.text:
strong in the world. If you love your country,
you want opportunities for your young people.

829.52.text:
If you love your country, you do not want
to act in a way that could lead to its break-up.

833.81.text:
That is why what I want to see is not Nigel
Farage’s little England, but a strong Britain

842.36.text:
>>Angus Robertson (Moray) (SNP): Last week,
thousands of dead from both sides in the battle

854.49.text:
of Jutland were remembered in commemorations
in which the Prime Minister joined the First

860.08.text:
Minister, the Princess Royal and the President
of Germany, along with thousands of other

864.85.text:
people, on Orkney to remember the tragedy
of so many people losing their life. European

872.15.text:
co-operation emerged from both world wars
as the best way to secure peace, so does the

877.95.text:
Prime Minister agree that we should never
take peace and security for granted, and that

882.55.text:
that is a strong reason to remain in the European
Union?

885.48.text:
>>The Prime Minister: The right hon. Gentleman
is absolutely right. There were very moving

891.21.text:
scenes as we stood on that cemetery ground,
with the British and German frigates in the

899.08.text:
background together in Scapa Flow—a sight
that I will not forget—as we commemorated

904.26.text:
and remembered how many people lost their
lives. I want to be clear about this: the

909.89.text:
words “world war three” have never passed
my lips, let me reassure everyone of that—[Interruption.]

915.56.text:
Of course, they have now; well spotted. But
can we really take for granted the security

925.82.text:
and stability we enjoy today, when we know
that our continent has been racked by so many

930.65.text:
conflicts in the past? Like all Conservatives,
I would always give the greatest credit to

935.51.text:
NATO for keeping the peace, but I think that
it has always been a Conservative view that

939.73.text:
the European Union has played its role as
well.

942.58.text:
>>Angus Robertson: This is not about world
war three, but about the realities—the facts.

948.41.text:
There have been wars on the European continent,
but outside the European Union; they have

954.25.text:
happened in the Balkans, in Ukraine and in
the Caucasus. It is a fact that there has

959.82.text:
never been a single example of armed conflict
between member states of the European Union.

968.63.text:
Will the Prime Minister, in the little time
that is left ahead of the European referendum,

974.10.text:
take the time to stress the positive advantages
of co-operation, peace and stability for us

980.83.text:
all, and not just of the single market or
the rights we have as citizens? Peace and

986.79.text:
prosperity are an advantage to us all, and
that is why we should remain in the European

992.14.text:
>>The Prime Minister: I very much take on
what the right hon. Gentleman says. I think

995.31.text:
that the strongest argument for the Government’s
position of wanting us to stay is that we

1000.24.text:
would be better off, and that that market
of 500 million people is essential for our

1005.63.text:
businesses. The argument that I was just making—that
we will be stronger in the world, in terms

1009.76.text:
of getting things done for Britain and for
our citizens—is important, but the argument

1014.18.text:
that we are safer and more secure because
the European Union is a means for dialogue

1019.19.text:
between countries that were previously adversaries
is one that I never forget. However frustrating

1023.96.text:
it can get around that table with 27 other
Prime Ministers and Presidents, I never forget

1028.88.text:
that these are countries that were previously
in conflict. Now, we talk, we discuss, we

1034.03.text:
argue and we decide, and that is a far better
way of doing things.

1037.12.text:
>>Mark Spencer (Sherwood) (Con): If my constituents
in the coalfields of Nottinghamshire are to

1044.12.text:
share in the economic success driven by this
Government, they need access to employment

1049.00.text:
via good-quality public services. Can the
Prime Minister give me any assistance in my

1054.29.text:
campaign to open up the Robin Hood line by
extending it to the villages of Ollerton and

1059.31.text:
Edwinstowe, so that we can get people on a
train and to a job?

1062.47.text:
>>The Prime Minister: My hon. Friend makes
a very important point. Quality infrastructure

1067.50.text:
is essential for our economy, and I am pleased
to say that following representations from

1071.97.text:
my hon. Friend and others, the Department
for Transport has revised the conditions for

1076.34.text:
its new stations fund, so that projects such
as the Robin Hood line that are in an earlier

1080.68.text:
stage of development can benefit from Government
money to kick-start them and get them going.

1085.45.text:
>>Ann Clwyd (Cynon Valley) (Lab): In 2003,
the current Prime Minister and most of today’s

1094.51.text:
Cabinet joined Tony Blair and his Cabinet
in voting for the war in Iraq. This is historically

1103.11.text:
factual and cannot be denied. Will not the
judgment of Chilcot be discredited if the

1110.15.text:
report fails to recognise that the then Prime
Minister honestly and genuinely believed that

1117.40.text:
his actions, given the information available,
were the right thing to do at the time?

1123.56.text:
>>The Prime Minister: What I say to the right
hon. Lady—I remember the powerful speeches

1129.25.text:
she made at the time and all the concerns
she had for people in Iraq, particularly the

1134.23.text:
Kurds—is that we should wait for the Chilcot
report and for what it has to say. I have

1140.90.text:
absolutely no idea what is in it, but what
I do know is that its publication is coming

1146.18.text:
>>Karl MᶜCartney (Lincoln) (Con): The European
Union recently admitted that it now has a

1151.96.text:
black hole in its finances of €24.7 billion—about
£19 billion. Eighteen months ago my right

1158.90.text:
hon. Friend declared that he would not pay
the EU a £1.7 billion surcharge—effectively

1162.59.text:
a fine on British taxpayers for growing our
economy—yet he was later forced to pay up.

1168.38.text:
What reassurance can he give the House that
hard-working British taxpayers will not be

1173.09.text:
forced to pour money into that EU black hole
if our nation votes to remain in the European

1177.55.text:
Union? Does he, like me, accept that our only
option to halt such payments is for our constituents

1182.85.text: to vote to leave the EU on 23 June?

1184.50.text:
>>The Prime Minister: The reassurance that
I can give my hon. Friend is that we fixed

1191.71.text:
the European budget for a seven-year period
between 2014 and 2020, and we fixed a total

1199.39.text:
for that budget that was lower than for the
previous seven-year period, which means that

1204.32.text:
European budgets are going to go down, not
up. That cannot be changed. This is a very

1209.73.text:
important point. That overall ceiling of spending
is determined by all 28 Prime Ministers and

1216.97.text:
Presidents. There is a veto over changing
it, just as there is a veto over the British

1221.72.text:
rebate. The only person who can give up the
British rebate is the British Prime Minister,

1226.97.text:
and as long as I am Prime Minister there is
absolutely no prospect of that happening.

1236.33.text:
As my hon. Friend ended his question with
a remark, I will end my answer with a remark:

1241.07.text:
there is no expert saying that we would make
a saving from leaving the EU. The only black

1247.91.text:
hole would be in our public finances, because
we would have a smaller economy and lower

1253.18.text:
tax receipts, so we would either have to cut
spending or put up taxes to make up for that

1259.22.text:
>>Alan Brown (Kilmarnock and Loudoun) (SNP):
It is time that buses, like trains, were required

1266.21.text:
to provide audiovisual information. This would
benefit not just those who are blind or deaf,

1271.62.text:
but many general users. I have written to
the Under-Secretary of State for Transport,

1274.02.text:
the hon. Member for Harrogate and Knaresborough
(Andrew Jones), on this subject. Will the

1277.18.text:
Prime Minister commit his Government to signing
up to an amendment to the Bus Services Bill

1280.63.text:
that would allow such a measure to be implemented
in order to provide accessibility for all?

1285.15.text:
>>The Prime Minister: I will look closely
at what the hon. Gentleman says. I think I

1290.06.text:
am right in saying that the Bus Services Bill
is a devolved matter, so it affects issues

1295.65.text:
in England rather than in Scotland, but let
me look carefully at what he says, because

1299.90.text:
we want to make sure that disabled people
can properly use our bus services.

1304.17.text:
>>Craig Mackinlay (South Thanet) (Con): My
right hon. Friend will be aware that it is

1309.30.text:
five years since the announcement by Pfizer
in Sandwich that it would scale down operations.

1314.59.text:
Since then, with enterprise zone status, there
has been a true renaissance of high-tech businesses

1319.45.text:
on the site, and employment levels are now
nearly up to where they were previously. My

1324.21.text:
right hon. Friend has previously promised
a trip to South Thanet. May I invite him once

1328.29.text:
more to see on site the success of Discovery
Park in my constituency?

1332.72.text:
>>The Prime Minister: I am delighted to answer
that offer and say yes, I would like to go.

1341.66.text:
I remember very well that it was early in
the 2010 Parliament when Pfizer made that

1348.38.text:
decision. There were real concerns that it
would lead to an exit of jobs and investment

1353.31.text:
from my hon. Friend’s constituency. I want
to pay tribute to David Willetts who, as Minister

1358.37.text:
of State for Universities and Science at the
time, did a great job working with others,

1362.36.text:
including with the local MP, to get businesses
to locate in the constituency, and to show

1366.56.text:
that there is a very strong pharmaceutical
and life sciences industry in our country,

1371.79.text: providing the jobs that we need.

1373.73.text:
>>Helen Goodman (Bishop Auckland) (Lab): With
industrialists such as GlaxoSmithKline and

1379.86.text:
Hitachi warning that if we left the EU, jobs
would be lost, the Brexit economist Patrick

1387.66.text:
Minford has revealed that under his side’s
strategy, manufacturing would be mostly eliminated.

1393.93.text:
Will the Prime Minister join me in calling
on the Brexit leaders to say how many other

1404.20.text:
people’s jobs they would sacrifice on the
altar of their own political ambitions?

1410.48.text:
>>The Prime Minister: The hon. Lady makes
an important point, which is that one of the

1414.91.text:
reasons why international companies such as
Hitachi invest in Britain—of course, we

1420.72.text:
also have excellent labour relations, the
English language, and a very hard-working

1424.90.text:
workforce and great engineers—is that we
are members of the single market. I thought

1430.34.text:
that what the head of Hitachi said this week
about wanting us to be the European headquarters,

1434.95.text:
and to manufacture those trains in the north-east
and sell them all over Europe, and how that

1439.52.text:
might not be possible if we were to leave,
was an incredibly powerful statement. In my

1445.16.text:
clear view, jobs come first, and if people
want to vote for jobs, they should vote for

1451.72.text:
>>Neil Carmichael (Stroud) (Con): Speaking
at many universities, colleges and schools

1457.92.text:
across England, and at events organised by
Universities UK, University Alliance and the

1465.54.text:
Russell Group, I have been struck by young
people’s strong interest in remaining in

1470.05.text:
the European Union. Does the Prime Minister
agree that Britain should take a firm lead

1476.58.text:
in the European Union to promote the interests
of young people’s careers and research,

1480.76.text:
and their opportunities in the future more
generally?

1483.65.text:
>>The Prime Minister: I think our universities
have been pretty much unanimous in recommending

1488.32.text:
that we vote to remain in the EU. I think
that is partly because of the opportunities

1493.30.text:
young people will have from being part of
a single market of 500 million people, but

1497.60.text:
also because our universities do very well
out of research funding that helps to create

1502.78.text:
the businesses and jobs of the future. We
contribute about 11% of the EU research budget,

1507.96.text:
but receive about 16% of the allocated funding.
Staying in Europe is good for students’

1514.51.text:
opportunities, good for young people’s opportunities
and good for our science base.

1517.52.text:
>>Steven Paterson (Stirling) (SNP): Yesterday
in the Defence Committee, the former First

1523.86.text:
Sea Lord, Admiral Lord West, commented that
the Ministry of Defence had effectively run

1527.79.text:
out of money for shipbuilding. Given reports
that another Russian submarine has had to

1532.26.text:
be escorted out of UK waters overnight, does
the Prime Minister share my concerns that

1536.56.text:
the delays to beginning work on new frigates
at the Clyde shipyards are causing real problems?

1542.56.text:
Does he agree that it is essential that the
money is allocated to deliver this programme

1548.22.text:
>>The Prime Minister: It is certainly not
the case that this country has in any way

1555.59.text:
run out of money, or run out of ambition,
when it comes to shipbuilding. We are currently

1560.48.text:
building the two largest ships the Royal Navy
has ever had. We will shortly be commissioning

1567.69.text:
the Type 26 programme, as well as the offshore
patrol vessels. The point I would make to

1573.25.text:
the hon. Gentleman is that there is only one
way we could threaten shipbuilding on the

1577.39.text:
Clyde, and that is by pulling out of the United
Kingdom and seeing jobs decimated as a result.

1584.54.text:
>>Dr Liam Fox (North Somerset) (Con): The
beauty of a referendum is that every voter

1592.20.text:
has an equal voice, every vote carries equal
weight, and Members of Parliament have no

1596.70.text:
moral or political superiority over anybody
else. Does my right hon. Friend accept that

1602.22.text:
the referendum is not a consultation but an
instruction to Parliament from the British

1606.84.text:
people? Is it not therefore incumbent on all
of us to accept in advance that remain would

1611.56.text:
mean remain and leave would mean leave, and
that any attempt to short-change or distort

1617.30.text:
the verdict of the British people would be
a democratic outrage?

1621.12.text:
>>The Prime Minister: My right hon. Friend
is absolutely right: every vote counts the

1627.41.text:
same. We have asked the British people for
their opinion, and we should treat their decision

1632.79.text:
as an instruction to deliver. I know many
people would like me to be a bit more nuanced

1639.14.text:
in what I think, and to say there are two
options that both have some merits and that

1643.90.text:
it is a balanced decision. That might have
made my life easier, but the problem is that

1647.40.text:
I do not believe it. I very strongly believe
that we are better off if we stay in. That

1652.65.text:
is why the Government and I are saying so
clearly to the British people: better off,

1658.16.text:
stronger, safer. But in the end, it is the
British people’s decision.

1662.28.text:
>>Matthew Pennycook (Greenwich and Woolwich)
(Lab): Only last week, the Prime Minister

1666.41.text:
was rightly extolling the virtues of the EU
as a means of tackling pollution, yet over

1671.83.text:
recent months the UK Government have led efforts
to water down a key EU directive aimed at

1676.95.text:
reducing the number of people who die every
year from breathing toxic air. Can he tell

1682.76.text:
>>The Prime Minister: What we are doing in
our own country is making sure that we improve

1686.90.text:
our air quality, and that we go for these
clean air zones. We have seen a major reduction

1691.97.text:
in particulates in the air over the past few
years, and we are going to continue doing

1697.45.text:
>>Mr Peter Bone (Wellingborough) (Con): What
the Prime Minister said today on Europe is

1702.90.text:
right: we have to go and campaign. I remember,
Mr Speaker, what you said yesterday about

1709.24.text:
notifying Members if one is going to visit
their constituency, so may I say to the Prime

1714.15.text:
Minister that a group of global-looking leave
campaigners will be descending on Witney at

1720.84.text:
lunch time this Sunday? I will be there. Will
the Prime Minister be able to join us? Given

1728.96.text:
what he has just said, will he confirm that
if the country votes to leave, he will be

1736.44.text:
able to stay on as Prime Minister and negotiate
the exit?

1740.65.text:
>>The Prime Minister: First, I am very sorry
that I will not be able to meet my hon. Friend—I

1748.17.text:
am making an appearance on the “Andrew Marr”
programme on Sunday—but I would recommend

1753.33.text:
that he goes to The Fleece pub in Witney and
spends as much time and as much money as he

1758.60.text: can there, rather than on anything else.

1759.60.text:
>>Dr Rupa Huq (Ealing Central and Acton) (Lab):
Will we have a decision on the Davies report

1767.88.text:
on airport expansion by the time the House
rises this summer, and does the Prime Minister

1772.56.text:
stand by his words: “No ifs, no buts, no
third runway at Heathrow”?

1777.30.text:
>>The Prime Minister: I absolutely stand by
what I said: that we will have a decision

1782.51.text:
about this in the summer, and we do need to
decide.

1785.36.text:
>>Fiona Bruce (Congleton) (Con): Next week,
the annual national parliamentary prayer breakfast

1792.04.text:
will take place in Westminster Hall, at which
600 community and faith leaders and over 100

1798.40.text:
MPs will gather. Yet also this week, we hear
of a Christian union being banned from holding

1803.75.text:
prayer and Bible study meetings, purportedly
on the grounds of the Government’s anti-terrorism

1809.31.text:
Prevent strategy. Does the Prime Minister
agree that such action was never the purpose

1814.32.text:
of a strategy intended to address terrorism
and extremism?

1818.17.text:
>>The Prime Minister: Of course what my hon.
Friend says is right. I am very sorry I will

1823.09.text:
not be able to attend the prayer breakfast,
because I know it is a very good event, and

1827.00.text:
it brings a lot of people together and means
a lot to Christians around our country. On

1832.49.text:
the point she makes about the Prevent duty
being misused, I have not heard of that exact

1838.25.text:
example, but it is clearly ludicrous. People
do need to exercise some common sense in making

1844.16.text:
these judgments, because it is quite clear
that that is not what was intended.

1847.03.text:
>>Alex Cunningham (Stockton North) (Lab):
Every day, around 6,000 people—many of them

1851.23.text:
children—take on new caring responsibilities,
providing unpaid care for an older or disabled

1856.03.text:
family member or friend, yet many carers tell
me they feel abandoned by everyone, including

1861.29.text:
the Government. In this Carers Week, will
the Prime Minister pledge that his Government

1865.04.text:
will do much better for the 9,500 carers in
my constituency, and the 6.5 million carers

1872.65.text:
>>The Prime Minister: I certainly take this
opportunity to pay tribute to carers across

1876.25.text:
our country for the selfless work they do,
for the immense amount of money that they

1880.52.text:
save taxpayers every year through what they
do, but, above all, for the love and commitment

1885.59.text:
that they give to the people they are caring
for. What we have done is try to help by,

1890.02.text:
for instance, increasing the number of carers’
breaks, because many carers will say to you

1893.99.text:
that the one thing they need to go on caring
is an occasional break and time away from

1898.84.text:
their caring responsibilities. We should continue
to work on all those things to help our carers.

1903.64.text:
>>Robert Neill (Bromley and Chislehurst) (Con):
The largest single source of employment and

1907.92.text:
wealth in my constituency is the London-based
financial services market. Does the Prime

1913.09.text:
Minister agree that the opportunity to continue
trading freely in a single market in financial

1920.58.text:
services of 500 million people and a completed
capital markets union is an unparalleled and

1927.83.text:
optimistic opportunity for my constituents,
and one that no sensible businessman would

1933.95.text:
>>The Prime Minister: My hon. Friend makes
an important point. Here, it really is worth

1939.20.text:
understanding exactly what this single market
means: it means that a financial services

1944.00.text:
company based in the UK effectively has a
passport to trade in 27 other EU countries.

1950.89.text:
If we are to leave, and if we leave the single
market, we lose that passport right, so, by

1957.42.text:
definition, many of the firms would have to
relocate at least some of their staff to another

1964.00.text:
European Union country. HSBC has said it would
have to scrap 1,000 jobs. JPMorgan said it

1969.72.text:
would have to scrap 4,000 jobs. Lloyd’s
came out and said that many jobs in insurance

1974.50.text:
would be under threat. This is a concrete
example of why the single market matters.

1979.63.text:
I would make the point—because this does
not just affect my hon. Friend’s constituency—that

1983.95.text:
two thirds of the jobs in financial services
are outside London, and this accounts for

1989.97.text:
7% of our economy, so when experts warn of
effects on jobs, growth and livelihoods in

1995.79.text:
our country, this is a classic example of
why they are right to make that case.

1999.58.text:
>>Stephen Kinnock (Aberavon) (Lab): Does the
Prime Minister agree that a vote to leave

2003.86.text:
on 23 June would be a hammer blow for the
British steel industry? Will he agree to meet

2010.76.text:
me to discuss a number of the decisions being
made in the context of the Tata sale process—imminent

2018.17.text:
decisions that will have a huge impact on
thousands of jobs in my constituency and right

2023.67.text:
>>The Prime Minister: I am working very closely
with the hon. Gentleman, as is my right hon.

2029.18.text:
Friend the Business Secretary, to help do
everything we can to secure a future for Tata

2033.56.text:
Steel. The sales process is progressing, and
that is encouraging. I would say that, yes,

2039.53.text:
for steel, we are better off inside the European
Union, because together as 28 countries, we

2045.96.text:
are far better able to stand up to the Chinese
or, indeed, the Americans over dumped steel.

2052.61.text:
Where we put in place those dumping tariffs,
you can see 95%, 98%, and 99% reductions in

2059.48.text:
the quantity of Chinese steel in those categories
being imported into the EU. We still face

2064.96.text:
a very difficult situation—there is still
massive overcapacity—but we are definitely,

2069.26.text:
for the steel industry, better off as part
of this organisation, fighting for British

2074.07.text:
>>Mr John Baron (Basildon and Billericay)
(Con): Will the Prime Minister address an

2077.29.text:
issue that the remain camp has so far fudged?
Our present immigration policy, in all truthfulness,

2084.17.text:
cannot control numbers coming in from the
EU to the benefit of our public services,

2088.52.text:
and also actually discriminates against the
rest of the world outside the EU.

2095.80.text:
>>The Prime Minister: Having spent my evening
yesterday with Mr Farage—or Farridge, as

2102.70.text:
I like to call him—I am confused about what
the leave camp actually wants when it comes

2109.41.text:
to immigration. I thought it wanted less immigration,
but now it seems to want more immigration

2114.34.text:
from outside the EU into our country. My view
is that we should restrict welfare in the

2120.56.text:
way that we have negotiated, so that people
have to come and work here for four years

2124.56.text:
before they get full access to our welfare
system—no more “something for nothing”;

2129.10.text:
people pay in before they get out—and then
we should focus on proper controls on migration

2133.73.text:
from outside the EU, on which we have made
some progress over recent years and can do

2139.31.text:
some more. That is the right answer. As for
the alternative of an Australian points system,

2143.68.text:
if we look at Australia, it has twice as much
immigration per head as we have here in the

2148.80.text: UK. That is not the right answer for Britain.

2151.03.text:
>>Stephen Gethins (North East Fife) (SNP):
As he reaches the end of his time in office,

2157.81.text:
President Obama has reflected that his worst
mistake was the catastrophe in Libya. What

2166.88.text:
is the Prime Minister’s worst mistake in
his time in office?

2170.25.text:
>>The Prime Minister: The time to reflect
on your mistakes is clearly when you are close

2174.49.text:
to the end of your time in office, so that
does not apply. [Interruption.]

2182.05.text:
>>Mr Speaker: I am sure the hon. Lady is delighted
to receive such a tumultuous cheer.

2190.05.text:
>>Helen Whately: Last week I was delighted
to welcome my right hon. Friend the Prime

2196.13.text:
Minister to Faversham in my constituency to
visit our largest local employer, Shepherd

2201.93.text:
Neame. There, we heard that having a strong
and stable economy is vital for the ongoing

2207.36.text:
success of Britain’s oldest brewery. Does
he agree that leaving the European Union would

2213.74.text:
put in jeopardy that strong economy, and with
it British businesses, British jobs, and British

2221.28.text:
>>The Prime Minister: My hon. Friend is right.
Shepherd Neame, which is the oldest brewery

2225.96.text:
in the country, could not have been clearer
about wanting to stay in a reformed European

2230.52.text:
Union, because it wants a strong and successful
economy, it wants to be part of a single market,

2235.46.text:
and it recognises that that is in our interests.
She and I very much enjoyed the pint of Spitfire

2241.01.text:
we had at about 10.30 in the morning—the
things we have to do to win this argument!

2244.85.text:
But we have an absolute commitment to carry
it through.

2247.59.text:
>>Mr Nigel Dodds (Belfast North) (DUP): Given
the number of people who will be travelling

2253.02.text:
from all parts of the United Kingdom, including
Scotland, I am sure, to the Euros next week—[Interruption.]

2259.12.text:
We 
welcome everybody, and given Leicester’s

2270.53.text:
success in the premiership, Northern Ireland,
at 150:1, is almost certain to win. Will the

2278.84.text:
Prime Minister ensure that given the number
of visitors, the security threats and all

2283.86.text:
the rest of it, the British embassy and consular
staff are fully geared up, resourced and staffed

2289.47.text:
to deal with the problems that will undoubtedly
arise?

2292.47.text:
>>The Prime Minister: I am very grateful to
the right hon. Gentleman for raising this

2296.91.text:
issue. I am sure that this is one occasion
when the whole House will want all the home

2301.24.text:
nations to stay in Europe for as long as possible.
[Interruption.] Come on now. I am going to

2311.28.text:
be watching; our first game is England-Russia,
and I will be watching very carefully to check

2315.62.text: that we get very strong support.

2317.98.text:
The right hon. Gentleman makes a very important
point, which is that this is a very big security

2324.04.text:
undertaking. Half a million people are planning
to leave the United Kingdom to go to this

2328.71.text:
tournament. We have set out very clear travel
advice, because people do need to know that

2334.91.text:
obviously there is a significant terrorist
threat in France today, and there is a potential

2341.58.text:
threat to this tournament. We have set out
very clearly that the threat level in France

2345.77.text:
is critical and the threat level for the tournament
is severe, and people need to know that. The

2351.43.text:
French security operation is enormous—77,000
police and gendarmes, 10,000 military personnel,

2357.69.text:
and 13,000 security guards. We are providing
additional counter-terrorism and public order

2362.15.text:
support to the French, including deployment
of additional police on trains to France and

2367.12.text:
more UK Border Force outbound checks. We are
also helping with sniffer dogs and in any

2371.64.text: other areas that the French ask us to.

2374.15.text:
We all want to see an absolutely great celebration
of European football. I wish all the home

2378.91.text:
nations well. It is brilliant that Northern
Ireland has made it to this tournament, and

2383.74.text:
I know we all—[Interruption.] And of course
Wales, and of course England. I look forward,

2389.48.text:
in the breaks in the campaign, to watching
some fantastic football.
